root.pub-comments: The Hmongic branch of this tree is taken primarily from Taguchi's classification (2013), and the Mienic branch is taken primarily from Ratliff (2010). “Although the highest-level two-branch structure is not in doubt given the obvious lexical, phonological, and grammatical differences between languages belonging to the two sub-families (Ratliff 1998), more work needs to be done to refine the internal structure of each sub-family” (Ratliff 2010:3).
root.publications: Taguchi, Yoshihisa. 2013. On the Phylogeny of Hmongic languages. Bangkok: 23rd Annual Meeting of the Southeast Asian Linguistics Society. , Ratliff, Martha. 2010. Hmong-Mien language history, vol. 613, 298. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858836157
root.geography: Spoken in southern China, and northern Vietnam, Laos, and Thailand

child.pub-comments: 5 million speakers. Ratliff (2010:3) describes the Hmongic sub-family as an “internally diverse group” with “mutually unintelligible languages, some with mutually unintelligible dialects.”
child.publications: Ratliff, Martha. 2010. Hmong-Mien language history, vol. 613, 298. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858836157, Taguchi, Yoshihisa. 2013. On the Phylogeny of Hmongic languages. Bangkok: 23rd Annual Meeting of the Southeast Asian Linguistics Society.

child.codes: cqd, hma, hmc, hme, hmf, hmg, hmh, hmn, hmp, hmv, hmw, hmy, hmz, hrm, sfm
child.geography: Spoken in Guizhou province (China), Yunnan province (China), and Southeast Asia.

child.pub-comments: Node not named by author. “Now, we can add that Ho Ne has two relatives, Kiong Nai and Pana, although the internal relationship is still unclear” (Taguchi 2013, slide 35).

child.pub-comments: Node not named by author. “Concerning the position of Pa Hng and Xiong, Ratliff (2010) made an important find that these lects preserve some phonological features that have been lost in other Hmongic lects” (Taguchi 2013, slide 14).
child.publications: Taguchi, Yoshihisa. 2013. On the Phylogeny of Hmongic languages. Bangkok: 23rd Annual Meeting of the Southeast Asian Linguistics Society.

child.pub-comments: 1.3 million speakers. “The Mienic sub-family is smaller and less internally diverse, but is represented over the entire geographical area, from Yunnan province in the southwest to Guangdong province in the southeast, and into northern Southeast Asia” (Ratliff 2010:3).
child.publications: Ratliff, Martha. 2010. Hmong-Mien language history, vol. 613, 298. Canberra: Pacific Linguistics. ISBN 0858836157, Taguchi, Yoshihisa. 2013. On the Phylogeny of Hmongic languages. Bangkok: 23rd Annual Meeting of the Southeast Asian Linguistics Society.
